io.github.nucleuspowered.nucleus.api.service

Interface NucleusAFKService


  • public interface NucleusAFKService
    Allows plugins to see a player's AFK status.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods Default Methods Deprecated Methods

      • setAFK

        boolean setAFK(org.spongepowered.api.event.cause.Cause cause,
               org.spongepowered.api.entity.living.player.Player player,
               boolean isAfk)
        Sets a player's AFK status, if the player can go AFK.
        Parameters:
        cause - The cause for going AFK. The root cause must be a PluginContainer.
        player - The player to set the status of.
        isAfk - Whether the player should go AFK.
        Returns:
        true if successful, otherwise false, usually because the player is exempt from going AFK.

      • disableTrackingFor

        @Deprecated
default java.lang.AutoCloseable disableTrackingFor(org.spongepowered.api.entity.living.player.Player player)
        Deprecated. Use disableTrackingForPlayer(Player, int) instead.
        Disables activity tracking for the specified Player for the next tick. See disableTrackingFor(Player, int) for more information on how to use this method.
        Parameters:
        player - Player to disable tracking for.
        Returns:
        The AutoCloseable that will re-enable the tracking when done.
        See Also:
        disableTrackingFor(Player, int)

      • disableTrackingForPlayer

        default NoExceptionAutoClosable disableTrackingForPlayer(org.spongepowered.api.entity.living.player.Player player)
        Disables activity tracking for the specified Player for the next tick. See disableTrackingFor(Player, int) for more information on how to use this method.
        Parameters:
        player - Player to disable tracking for.
        Returns:
        The AutoCloseable that will re-enable the tracking when done.
        See Also:
        disableTrackingFor(Player, int)

      • disableTrackingFor

        @Deprecated
default java.lang.AutoCloseable disableTrackingFor(org.spongepowered.api.entity.living.player.Player player,
                                                               int ticks)
        Deprecated. Use disableTrackingForPlayer(Player, int) instead.
        Disables activity tracking for the specified Player for up to the number of ticks specified.

        This method returns an AutoCloseable, and as such, the recommended way of using this method is using "try with resources": 

             try (AutoClosable dummy = disableTrackingFor(player, 1)){
         // perform actions here, most likely something like:
         player.setLocation(location);

         // Any actions here will not disable the AFK timer.
     }

     // any actions here that move the player will be tracked again.

        This pattern isn't strictly required, as the AutoCloseable will close itself after the specified number of ticks. However, it's prudent to consider the following:

        • This method will reset the tracking on the main thread. This means if you use this async (though usually, you wouldn't do so), you will possibly find that the tracking will re-enable before the task finishes on the defaults. Minimise the amount of time the activity tracking must be disabled, and consider increasing the tick count slightly.
        • There is no need to increase the tick parameter on the main thread. Consider using disableTrackingFor(Player) for a sane default.

        If you do not use "try with resources", call the close method upon completion to reactivate tracking.

        Parameters:
        player - The Player to disable tracking for.
        ticks - The number of ticks to disable tracking for.
        Returns:
        The AutoCloseable that will re-enable the tracking when done.

      • disableTrackingForPlayer

        NoExceptionAutoClosable disableTrackingForPlayer(org.spongepowered.api.entity.living.player.Player player,
                                                 int ticks)
        Disables activity tracking for the specified Player for up to the number of ticks specified.

        This method returns an AutoCloseable, and as such, the recommended way of using this method is using "try with resources": 

             try (AutoClosable dummy = disableTrackingFor(player, 1)){
         // perform actions here, most likely something like:
         player.setLocation(location);

         // Any actions here will not disable the AFK timer.
     }

     // any actions here that move the player will be tracked again.

        This pattern isn't strictly required, as the AutoCloseable will close itself after the specified number of ticks. However, it's prudent to consider the following:

        • This method will reset the tracking on the main thread. This means if you use this async (though usually, you wouldn't do so), you will possibly find that the tracking will re-enable before the task finishes on the defaults. Minimise the amount of time the activity tracking must be disabled, and consider increasing the tick count slightly.
        • There is no need to increase the tick parameter on the main thread. Consider using disableTrackingFor(Player) for a sane default.

        If you do not use "try with resources", call the close method upon completion to reactivate tracking.

        Parameters:
        player - The Player to disable tracking for.
        ticks - The number of ticks to disable tracking for.
        Returns:
        The AutoCloseable that will re-enable the tracking when done.
